item.description: A simple game of air combat over Vietnam based on the Space Fury tactical space combat rules. Statistics are given for two fighters (F-4E and Mig-17) and design rules allow the players to construct their own aircraft. The game features air-to-air combat with missiles and guns, as well as ground attack. All maneuvering is two dimensional, there are no altitude rules.

"Each player controls an A-10 Thunderbolt II (The Warthog) on Close Air Support Duty."

The game is played with a custom deck of cards shared by all players. The deck includes Mission Cards, Munitions Cards, Enemy Cards, and Event Cards.

Mission Cards are ground targets of various Mission Point values. A player who successfully attacks the target wins the Mission Card and adds the Mission Points to his score. Enemy Cards, representing a variety of Soviet air and ground threats, are played against opposing players. Munitions Cars represent bombs, missiles, or other payload items which aid in attack or defense. Event Cards offer a variety of bonuses and can be played at various times as specified on the particular card.

There are also six named Pilot Cards that are not a part of the main deck. At the start of the game each player randomly selects one Pilot Card. Each pilot has a special advantage.

Fuel and ammo counters are used to track each plane's status. The aircraft are required to return to base to refuel and rearm. Damage can also force a plane to return to base where the damage is repaired.

The object is to have the most Mission Points at the end of the game.

"Dice game for 2 players. WWI theme. Ariel Dogfight. One player is a British Sopwith Camel. The other is a German Fokker Triplane. Victory: Shoot your opponent out of the skies."

Each player has five dice: a 20-sided die representing Visibility (from the aircraft), a 12-sided die representing Speed, a 10-sided die representing Maneuverability, an 8-sided die representing Firepower, and a 6-sided die representing Defense.

The Sopwith receives positive die roll modifiers for Visibility and Speed and the Fokker receives positive modifiers for Maneuverability and Defense. Neither aircraft has a bonus in Firepower.

The players roll all their dice each turn and compare them to determine a result. If the result of the dice places one of the aircraft in firing position with a higher Firepower score, the target must roll on the Damage table for a result. This ranges from destruction of the aircraft to damage which reduces the value of certain dice for that aircraft.

The game also includes rules for stalling (when a 1 is rolled on the maneuver die) and Ace Pilot skills.

A solitaire pencil and paper game which simulates an American Rolling Thunder Bombing Mission during the Vietnam War, circa 1966.

The player's force consists of 16 F-105 bombers (Thuds), 8 F-105 Wild Weasels, 10 F-4 Phantom fighters, and 2 EB-66 jamming aircraft. The attack force must locate and attack targets. When a target is located, the player decides how many bombers will attack it. Each bomber can only make one bombing run per game. The force will also encounter hostile SAM (surface to air missile) sites and MiG-21 fighters.

Victory is determined by Objective Points. Points are gained for every target bombed, SAM site destroyed, and enemy MiG fighter shot down. Points are lost for each American plane lost.

The game is played with a six-sided die (or two), a pencil, and the game sheet. The game lasts twenty-five turns.

The game about one of the greatest WW2 battles.

Map is double-sided (summer and autumn version).

The game uses rules of the "WB95" (Great Battles 1939-1945) system designed for dealing with large battles of World War II. Counters represent regiments (Germans) or divisions (Russians), one hex represents about 2500m, one turn represents one day.

"Solo Dice Game. Simulation of an Air War between USA and an imaginary Middle Eastern Nation."

The game is played with paper, pencil, a ten-sided die, and one or two six-sided dice.

"The player plays the commander of Anti-Aircraft troops of an imaginary Middle Eastern Nation. The goal is to bring down ten American war planes to create anti-war sentiment in the USA and halt the American assault."

"Card game for 2+ players. Theme: Migrations/Conquests of Asiatic Nomads. Victory: The first player to accumulate 12 Loot Points is the winner."

The players all start off as Nomads. The player who wins the card contest in the Invasion Phase becomes the Khan. Only the Khan can score Loot points.

In subsequent Invasion Phases, Nomad players attempt to play cards to weaken the Khan's rule. If they are successful, the Khan will become a Nomad again and on the next turn all of the players will have a chance to become the Khan.

"Card game for 2 players. Simulates the Iran- Iraq War of 1980-88. One player uses the Iraq deck. The other player uses the Iran deck."

Each turn represents a battle where the players are seeking to play cards with a higher total Force value. Some cards provide special advantages, others disadvantage your opponent. There are twelve types of cards in the game: Offensive, Defense, Air Raid, Leadership, Intelligence, Blunder, Economic Advantage, Military/Morale Advantage, Political Advantage, Military Unit, Weapon, and Fighting.

"Victory: A game lasts 16 turns. The player with the most Victory Points at the end of the game wins. If a player is ever able to win 3 victory points in 3 consecutive turns, he automatically wins."

"Card game for 2+ players. Each player controls a Jedi with a light saber. Takes place in the Star Wars Universe. Each figure represents a Jedi knight."

The game is played on a 5x5 grid. Miniatures or chits are used to represent the combatants. A custom card deck is used by both players. The appropriate cards must be played to allow units to move or attack.

Statistics for ten Jedi from the Star Wars movies are included. Each is described by Rank (Apprentice, Jedi, or Master), Jedi Ability, and Heroic Ability.

To win the game you must reduce your opponent to zero Force Points by making successful attacks.

The players compete to see who can kill Rasputin.

The game uses a custom deck of 52 cards. There are five types of cards: Method, Conspiracy, Location, Save, and Fate.

The players attempt to play melds of cards of the same type. Once you have three melds in play (one each for Method, Conspiracy, and Location), you may make an Assassination Attempt die roll to see if you kill Rasputin. If the roll is not successful, you lose some or all of your melds and the game continues.

A player who is unable to play a meld on a turn must roll on the Event table and take the specified action.

"Board game for 2+ players. Science Fiction theme. Players are Rival Mad Scientists bent on World Domination. Victory: Destroy all Enemy Bases."

The game is played on a chess board or any other 8x8 grid. There are four types of counters in the game - Units, Bases, Modifiers, and Specials.

The players each receive one base at the start of the game. Every turn the players receive two counters, drawn randomly from a pile. Some counters add to the player's offensive capabilities, while others represent new bases and improvements for bases.

Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
"Card game for 2 players. Theme: Russia’s war with Afghanistan 1979-1988. The Decks: One player is the Soviets. The other player is the Afghans. Each player has his own deck. Play also requires 3 Pacification counters."

The Russian card deck consists of the following types of cards: Mission, Strategy, Units, Weapons, Politics, and Leaders. The Afghan deck includes Units, Weapons, Leaders, Advantage, Morale, and Strategy cards.

"Game End: The game ends when the Russian player has no cards left in his deck. Victory: The Soviets win if they ever get 3 Pacification counters. The Afghans win if the game ends before this."

"Simple tactical skirmish rules. Based on the classic movie Seven Samurai." Seven Samurai and forty villagers face off against thirty-seven heavily armed bandits.

The game is played on a hex map showing the village being protected by the Samurai. The counters represent men, horses, guns, armor, and wounds.

"Victory: The Bandits win if all the Samurai are killed. The Samurai win if the Leader, lieutenants, and 15 bandits are killed. The remaining bandits will flee."

This is a simple hand-management and pattern matching game.

The hexes are colored to form "flowers" at the Y shaped intersection of three tiles. Player manage a hand of 5 tiles and play tiles into a growing pattern, trying to complete as many flowers as possible.

"Solo variant of Zulu Spears Card game. Simulates a battle between Zulu & British Troops. To be played on British side."

The game uses two custom decks of cards, one deck for each side. The British deck is the same as the two player game, but the Zulu deck uses a different composition of cards.

The player seeks to hold out until the Zulu retreat. The player loses if all British soldiers are killed.

"Card game. Simulates a battle between Zulu & British Troops."

One player represents the Zulu forces and the other player is the British. Each side has its own custom deck of 52 cards. Through card play the British may build fortifications, Zulu snipers can attack, and British sharpshooters can fire back.

The Zulu player also gets to decide whether or not there is a melee attack each turn. When the players do battle, the Zulu player tries to inflict casualties by playing cards having a higher total Force Value than those played by the British player.

"Zulu Victory: If all 100 of the British troops are killed than the Zulu win."

"British Victory: If the Zulu player goes to draw a card and there are no cards left in his deck and the British player still has troops remaining, than the Zulu give up and go home, and the British win."

Inside Pitch Baseball Game:

ISG is proud to announce Inside Pitch Baseball.

This game is based upon the Defense Independent Pitching Statistics, developed by Vörös McCracken. This is a statistic that operates under the revolutionary and controversial theorem that a pitchers value comes from his strikeouts, walks, and home runs allowed (because these are the only events over which the pitcher has total control).

Each at bat starts on the pitchers card and while one of the outcomes from above (K, BB or HR) may come into play each batter has the final say. The game includes split LH/RH ratings for all pitchers and hitters with at least 40 BF/AB against each side. Defensive plays such as range plays and errors are interwoven into the game so as to make it seamless. All action comes from the players cards so outside chart lookups to determine the outcome of at bats are a thing of the past.
Hitters are not left out as they are rated for where they actually hit the ball in the year represented. Base running, stealing and bunting can be handled by the game engine for the solitaire player as well.

Ballparks play a big part in IP. Now each park will have its own card (look just like a hitter card) that is referenced during game play. Ballparks will be represented on more than just HRs allowed. All hits, strikeouts and walks will be affected by the place a game is being played. Just by looking at the ballpark cards you will see that the Astrodome will yield few HR chances while Coors Field will earn its rep as the launching pad.
These ballpark cards have been seamlessly added to the game as well by not requiring any outside lookups. They have also give the opportunity to add rare plays and the "trying to stretch" hits in the game.

We have completed a sample game run through that shows how the game plays along with pictures to guide you the IP game play. It can be found at http://forums.delphiforums.com/ISGF/messages?msg=214.1 .

IP takes a unique approach to simulating the game of baseball. From where you start with the pitchers card to how the defense gets involved the game just feels right. So forget the 50/50 setup, forget the chart lookups and step inside the game of baseball with Inside Pitch.

item.description:
The year is 1947. Throughout the world, three major superpowers fight to claim exclusive control over a revolutionary source of power: Vk. Elite troops and massive combat robots wage violent battles to control these energy reservoirs...

Dust Tactics is a tactical miniatures board game for 2-4 players. In an alternate 1940s reality, alien technology fuels gigantic machines of war as the forces of the Axis and Allies clash over rare mineral deposits that could inevitably decide the outcome of the war. With over 30 highly detailed miniatures, nine double-sided terrain boards, 12 custom dice, unit cards, terrain, and plastic scenery, Dust Tactics delivers everything you need to wage battles in the immersive world of Dust.

A deep and engaging game setting, featuring stunning artwork by Paolo Parente, will draw players into a world desperately at war... and the highly detailed miniatures only add to this immersion. Eight included scenarios and nearly limitless customization ensures hundreds of hours of replayability, while scalable rules offer a satisfying experience for players of all levels.

• Over 30 highly detailed miniatures
• Nine double-sided boards to customize your own battle
• A deep and engaging setting
• A battle book including eight unique scenarios
• Quick-start rules to get into the action quickly

item.description:
The British Army's take on operational wargaming from it's OR experience in WWII and Korea. It was designed to explore the potential of theatre nuclear weapons in hypothetical battles of the early Cold War era.

At its core is a recently de-classified set of rules by Lt. Col. Field found by Bob Cordery in the UK National Archives, and is published with suggested amendments and augmentations for the wargamer by the publisher, John Curry.

It uses a "kriegsspiel" format with a central umpire (controller) to implement the rules and feed relevant information to two sets of players. The umpire is there to provide information and implement the rules, not make his own assessments.

It works with orders given on an hourly basis to units on a 1:50,000 scale map or terrain model. Units are armour, infantry, artillery and engineers in battalion squadron and regimental sized units that operate, broadly, in 2km map squares. Combat resolution is probability driven and focusses on the need for TIME to plan co-ordinated assaults in attack or increase defence strength by preparing and digging in. One of the main purposes of the wargame was to allow officers to experiment with tactical nuclear warfare.

These are playable rules, but also a work of reference about operational warfare between 1940 and 1970.

Obtained from www.wargaming.co

link.value: Lt. Col. G. W. H. Field

item.description: Collect 'runs' of sequential letters from hand and available draw cards. Helps teach the alphabet.

A game of hunting the Wumpus. Each player is a hunter trying to be the first to kill the beast.

The game is played on a 7x7 array of terrain tiles. The Lair of the Wumpus is placed in the center and the hunting camps are at the four corners. The remaining spaces are randomly placed terrain tiles (clear, forest, swamp, and rocky.) The hunters start in their individual hunting camps and the Wumpus starts in the Lair.

Each player holds a hand of five cards. Cards are played to attack the Wumpus when a player is in the same square as the beast. The opposing players have the opportunity to play Evade cards to help the Wumpus evade the attack. Terrain only affects combat. Each type of Evade card is more successful in a certain type of terrain.

House of Tudor includes 5 pewter miniatures 35 mm high, including a Tudor king, queen, gentleman, bishop, and jester, as well as a 4 x 10 checkerboard and 12 lines of rules. One player takes starts four pieces at one end of the board, able to move only forward, and the other takes one piece at the other end, able to move orthogonally. A player wins by getting a piece to the end of the board.
The same rules and board are sold with numerous other collections of pewter figures.

The aim is very simple, to help Maisy race along to meet her friends in this colour-matching and counting game. Two ways to play depending upon the players skill level by using either the colour spinner or the number dice to advance. Spin the spinner and get a colour, move to the next square of that coulour. Roll the dice and get a number, move that number of squares, but don't get caught behind the gate!

Ages 3 and up

From the rules:

Truckers deliver a variety of packages everyday! Competition is fierce among them. Once day they got together and Ms. Ponytail said, "Let's have a race to determine who will earn the most money in three days."

So, who will be the winner during those busy three days? You can be a trucker by playing this game, The Truckers. Can you be the most successful trucker in town!

Use the 8 cards in your hand to move your truck around the city to pick up goods, load them on to your truck. Then pick up a new truck at the end of day 1 and day 2, but be careful... if you have empty trucks or if you have goods that have not been picked up when the game ends it will cost you money.

Whoever has the most money at the end of the game wins!

The board has tiles around it, every time a pawn ends in a tile, must fight another player to take over it; when it ends up in an Event tile, must draw a card from the event deck and fight creatures.

Fights won and areas controlled earn players victory points.

Loose translation from the game box:

MUNDO ARCANA Conquistadores del Dragon (Conquerors of the Dragon) A board full of dangers, lands to conquer, challenges to overcome, a nation to raise

Contents:
1 game board
50 challenges cards
12 conqueror cards
10 land cards
6 pawns
2 dice
Rules booklet

The slap-happy "feed-the-hungry-animals" action game!

Snackin' Safari is an action game that helps preschool adventurers with their coordination, counting and motor skills. This small table top game has 4 animals on the sides and a safari man in the center. All of the players tap their animals to get Safari Sam to spin. When Safari Sam spins, the snack disks in his "hands" fly off. The player who catches the most snacks wins.

Components:
FPT11101 - Green base with 4 animals on the sides: orange tiger head, green alligator head, yellow lion head, and grey elephant head. There is a safari man in the center that holds the accessory snack disks.
16 round plastic snack disks

This is a variation on Monopoly, produced by the DMC Corporation, who makes embroidery floss. This version is thread and needlecrafting themed. Instead of properties, players collect stitching techniques.

According to the website at http://www.dmc-usa.com/majic/pageServer/1l0100028r/en_US/Stitch-opoly.html
, all property cards also feature a stitch diagram for the design on the card.

Around 1300 a supernatural event opened a few breaches between two distant worlds: ours and the world of FATAL. Following this event, the Queen of Fatal disappeared and a few enchanters left that world and arrived on Earth.

The five breaches in Europe gave origin to as many magic birth-signs: Flambeaux (Paris), Aquaté (Brno), Terranova (Rome), Ångbåt (Tallinn), Lichtenborn (Nuremberg). Five families who over the centuries kept wavering between open war and armed peace, but who never lived in harmony.

Since then, the enchanters have influenced humans politics, arts and science: either directly or by inspiring and taking control over all humans who were useful for their cause, and FATAL is a piece of this tale.

The game features a deck of 110 cards. Each player belongs to one of the birth-signs and tries to catch the greater number of treasures by playing "trimagics" (combination of three cards) and/or beating other players.

During his turn, the player:

 may play a special "enchantment" card,
 may steal a card in front of another player (with a rock-paper-scissors system printed on the cards),
 may play up to two cards in front of himself.




Each player has two "virtual" columns where he can play cards: the first card of a column is played normally, the second card is played rotated by 180°, the third card completes the column (the "trimagic") and must be placed rotated by 90°.
The three cards of a tri-spell have a different meaning: the first card decides the performed action, the second one fixes the number of targets or the power of the spell, the third one closes the trimagic.

Each player has also a designed enemy (by secret role assignment at the start of the game): if he defeats this player, he is the winner. If nobody reaches this goal, the winner is the player with the most powerful treasures at the end of the game.

One of the authors, Martina Mealli, she is also the illustrator of the cards.

Re-implements:

 F.A.T.A.




Home Page: http://www.fatal.it/

item.description:
Action of game take place in medieval Malopolska - region of Kingdom of Poland. Players are playing roles of knights, settlers, merchants and pilgrims. Their job is to help prince Boleslaw and princess Kinga in rebuilding province after invasion of Tartars.Players can establish towns, salt mines, castles, they are fighting with Tartars, robbers, and taking part in process of canonization of local sacrosant 
Game is in Polish.

Developed and published in 1940, Modern Warfare looks to be a self-published game as no publisher is listed and the game is copyrighted by the designers. The rules boast 3 games in one, the main game is Modern Warfare, a "game that fills up a long standing demand for a war game and introduces you to our latest mechanical inventions and the rapid development of their uses as weapons of destruction in the present day war operations". Additionally there is a wargame, called "Trench Warfare", based on the old styles of warfare and finally a simple "Hit and Miss" game.

Modern Warfare uses large (1.25 inch) lead Soldiers, Aircraft, Tanks and Artillery as units in the game and they are initially placed in one of four lines (3 main lines and the reserve).

The main game begins with the firing of a single artillery piece on each side for 4 turns (a spinner is spun for combat results and movement) followed by an artillery barrage (both artillery pieces fire on each side) until one side loses both their guns. Then the winning side gets 3 more shots and moves and attacks with his air and tank units in the first line. The other side then moves all air and tank units in the first rank. This alternates until one side has lost all their units.

The winning side retires their remaining air and tanks to the reserve and the infantry then fights alone... Terrain can be destroyed on the map (indicated by placing a red square on the destroyed item).

Fascinating instructions with detailed play throughs and fairly complicated rules depending on the unit type and position (line) the unit occupies.

"Ikko" - one, a fragment, single

"Zendo" - the way of Zen, a mind-expanding game

"Ikkozendo" - a whole game of Zendo in one pocket!

Ikkozendo is a variant of Zendo that is played with a limited number of people who all are present at the game start. All must be present at game start because Ikkozendo is a single stash game and, as such, there will not be enough pyramids for the Students to build koans to seek the secret rule or for the Master to build koans to disprove a rule guess. Because no more than two koans are made during a game, the players' memory of previous configurations of the koans is critical to finishing the game. Thus, if players come and go, as is allowed in Zendo, then the game can get stuck in "cycles," as the same configurations are reused over and over again to disprove already-attempted guesses.

Crossin' Colors is played in a 7X7 grid.

Each player has to get his pawn across the board "waling" over the stones of the corresponding color. 
Initially all stones are placed randomly in the board, 9 stones for each of the 5 colors in the game.
The player's move is to insert a stone in a row or column, shifting all the stones in that row or column and grabbing the last one to be used for the next turn.
Changing the stones disposition on the board will, eventually, allow the player to move across the board reaching the other side.

item.description:
The Bandthology tour-bus is pulling out, and you need to be on it! What type of music do you like? Rock, Hip-Hop, Country, Jazz, Blues... this game is as individual as you are. The object of BANDthology is to be the first individual or team to win 6 musicians to form your own Supergroup. Bandthology is unique, in that it appeals to music lovers of all ages and different musical interests.

BANDthology the board game features:


 "Musicology" cards that feature music trivia, presented as true or false questions, multiple choice, fill in the blanks, word unscrambles & open ended questions that really make you think on your feet. 
 "Play" cards which challenge each player to provide "Open Ended" responses, (eg. Name 3 songs with an animal in their title, 3 artists that end with the letter T, song title that contains the word "House") 
 "Now What?" cards either help or hurt your progress (eg. Your van broke down on the way to the gig, move back 3 spaces, or Congratulations! You just won a city wide song writing contest, collect the musician you are currently pursuing.)
 "Now What? Audition" cards, which are musical themed charades.

Each player is given six dice. All players roll one of their dice and hide it with their hand. Players make successively higher declarations regarding the results of all pips on the dice rolled, e.g. "seven pips". However, someone can always contest the bid, calling the bidder a pipsqueak. When that happens, all the dice are revealed, the pips are counted, and either the bidder or the caller loses their die, depending on who was correct. The last player with dice is the winner.

Each scientist starts with 10d6 which represent atoms placed within a particle accelerator. Scientists compete with each other by selecting from one to three atoms with differing charges to accelerate towards other player's atoms within the atom smasher. The player with the most electric charges at game's end wins.

Live Action Risk (Lark) enables groups of all sizes to experience Risk in a simplified form. A party game of allegiances, war, and conquering other countries, Lark can be played inside or outside with each player representing a country of the world. Players battle each other with d6's, with the winner conquering and controlling the vanquished country. As a ruling world power, your vassals have to comply with your every whim. But watch out! If you lose a combat, you become the lackey of another world leader!

High Roller is a game which contains two card games:
High Roller Casinos and High Roller Superskins.
Superskins has the focus of betting on the card play between the dealer and one player. The betting is on the outcome, Dealer to win, Player to Win or Stand Off.
Casinos is a betting game with continuous involvement and fast moving action.
In both games two players play the cards and the other plays bet on the outcome of the game, and rounds can be played so that everyone has a turn at being a dealer, player and a better.
Game components:
One Plastic coated pack of 72 High Roller Casino Cards
Eight suites of players betting cards
Rules for both games playable

Fraperdeck Original is designed to encourage students to learn the relationship between fractions, decimals and percents. Fraperdeck has added a clever educational twist to commonly played games such as “War”, “Crazy 8” and more. This unique instructional format offers a FUN alternative to other methods.

Conversion charts and instructions for 4 different games are included.

Ages 7 and up, 2 or more players

Tactical level miniature wargame rules covering the Wars of Marlborough, Peter the Great, William of Orange and Prince Eugene (1688-1717).

Figure scale: 1 figure = 60 men

Expanded by:

 To Arms!

"Full" title: In the Land of Egypt... You'll find 8 great games about ancient times.

A small collection of games in a single box... Includes 30 Pyramid Cards, 30 Mummy Cards, 15 Rhyme Cards, 2 Egyptian Dice, and a rule booklet

From the box: In the Land of Egypt bring the dark secrets of ancient Egypt to light while reinforcing the educational curriculum. Children will see ho ancient engineers used science and math to build pyramids. Through storytelling and rhyme, they will learn about Egyptian life and mythology. Probability and problems solving will help them master exotic dice games.

name.value: Ghost Wiry Dan's Electronic Word Game

item.description:
Ghost Wiry Dans's Electric Word Game consists of two interconnected word tracks. The word tiles are placed face up, so you can choose to spell any word, but the electronics in the game vary the turn order, so your opponent may be able to spell their word first, even if it's longer.

The cover shows two small children, one of which has been possessed by a smiling ghost. It also shows a robotic figure, which I can only assume is "Wiry Dan."

W. C. Fields Chickadee Poker is a unique take on poker which includes a bit of role-play associated with the comedy of W. C. Fields prior to the actual poker on each hand.

The box has a great B&W illustration of W. C. Fields on the cover of the box, and the DOW chemical logo. There is an advertisement for DOW Oven Cleaner on the inside of the lid. The lid is attached to the box bottom and it opens like a book. Inside is a vinyl mat, thin cardboard poker chips, a non-standard deck of cards, and a rule book entitled W. C. Fields Chickadee Poker Rules; all emblazoned with images, either photographs or cartoons of W. C. Fields. All of the face cards show scenes and quote from W. C. Fields films. The components are kept in place by a thin plastic shield.

There are a lot of humorous aspects to the rules befitting the notorious character of W. C. Fields.

From GMT Games:

"The Napoleonic Wars, 1805 - 1815, brings you a fast-paced, tension-filled, card-driven wargame using a point-to-point movement system that pushes the envelope in a new direction for this pivotal period of history. Having a simple-to-learn strategic system and short rulebook, The Napoleonic Wars, can be played in an evening as the cards and Diplomatic Track make for tough decision-making in the face of everchanging enemy threats.

Set in 1805 Europe, you must weigh the strategic dilemmas facing the two alliances in mortal conflict. Napoleon's France enjoys a superb army, central position, superior leadership, and a useful, if not powerful, ally in Spain. However, she faces three foes.

Napoleon must beware of Britain's seapower and wealth, Austria's threatening position, and Russia's reinforcing hordes. In the wings, Prussia, Turkey, and Sweden teeter on the brink of war, begging inducements to join either side. Even lowly Denmark's fleet can upset the balance of power.

When fleets or armies collide, battle-related cards may be played and then dice are rolled to resolve the battle and inflict casualties. Even the most brilliant maneuver faces the chance of floundering. So play The Napoleonic Wars now, and put the strategist in you to the test. Your options are only limited by your vision, a meddlesome enemy's cards, and the hand of fate."

Expanded by:

 Napoleonic Wars: Super Deluxe Map




Re-implements:

 The Napoleonic Wars

item.description:
The Guns of Gettysburg is a simulation of the largest battle of the American Civil War. Like Bowen Simmons's previous games, Bonaparte at Marengo and Napoleon's Triumph, The Guns of Gettysburg uses a diceless and cardless system for governing movement and resolving combat. Units in the game are represented by linear blocks rather than the traditional hex and counters, giving the game an appearance that evokes 19th-century battlemaps.

The Guns of Gettysburg has simple rules and fast play but still reflects the historical limitations of the actual conflict. Though it preserves the aesthetics and "fog of war" mechanisms of Bonaparte at Marengo and Napoleon's Triumph, The Guns of Gettysburg is neither a sequel nor a successor to either game but a wholly new system of its own.

item.description:
Official Site: http://www.lineageboards.com/

Lineage is a two-player, turn-based, abstract strategy game designed by Ray Li at age 16 for a school project. It is played on a board of intersecting ovals and lines.

The Objective: Capture the four center points.

Game Setup: You start the game with ten of your pieces on or within the starting oval, and the other two on the center points on your right.

Game Mechanics: On each turn, you must either move one of your pieces or force an enemy piece.

--Moving your own pieces: A piece may move to any intersection along the lines it is on, unless another piece is in its way. Also, every line that goes off the board is connected to the other side of itself.

--Forcing an enemy piece: If an enemy piece is surrounded on all sides except one and one of your pieces is behind the enemy piece, you may force the enemy piece through the open intersection (see detailed explanation on the official website).

--Piece elimination: You can eliminate pieces by surrounding them.

Lineage can be purchased directly from the publisher's website: LineageBoards.

Based on the novel "Maker Of Universe" By Philip José Farmer

Only one way to become the best Makers of the Universe to be the first to build its own world. But be careful because the path is strewn with pitfalls and friends of a tour will be the enemies of the next.

For this you need to buy machinery for building developments such as water or wildlife. You must protect your world by installing traps to your door, throw creatures to slow players and use your creative powers.

The game is divided into towers themselves divided into 2 phases.

During the first phase is named "Buy" players play together. A map "Machine" is drawn, then each player proposes a secret "Units of energy" in their closed fist. Whoever has the highest placing the machine wins.

Therefore, it must open the doors of his world to repatriate the machine and can use it.

During the phase of actions, each player in turn, plays many cards in his hand as they wish. The possibilities are: 
Play-card creature in defence to protect its World enemy attacks 
Play-card creature in launching the attack on another world. 
Play-card trend to build its world if we have the machine that goes well 
- Protecting the world map by a trap or a decoy

In addition, each player represents one of the 10 characters available and has a unique power affecting the game It may also use the cards type action at any time during the game, a turn or not.

Between developments and machinery, points creations (annotated by stars on the charts) are earned. The first to reach the required number of points (defined according to the number of players) won the game.

Online Play: VASSAL module

item.description:
This game is from Miro's les jeux "gais loisirs" series (roughly, "happy leisure games").

Something like a updated Bingo with memory aspects, this game contains six cards containing animal pictures in various orders, a pack of 48 animal cards, rules, and oodles of purple wooden discs (to mark the animals called).

Roughly translated from the box bottom: "A new game of Bingo where animals replace numbers. Original rules make for an interesting game for both children and adults."

A complete remake of the classic SPI and Avalon Hill versions from the 1970's. While the original game featured largely the classic hex and counter movement that was prevalent in the 70's. This new version will feature features area-movement, action points for movement and a new card deck (that adds random events without driving the game). Players will use cards for both events and action points and at the same time being able to play cards during their opponent's turns to counter their efforts.

Players can play one of four European powers competing for control of the resources of the new world. The game's time line goes from 1495 to 1615 with players trying to establish colonies in the Americas and bring home as much gold and resources as they can back to Europe. Along the way they will have to deal with natural disasters, other European powers and of course the indigenous people of the New World including the Mayans, Incas and Aztecs.

item.description:
Kamelipeli (The Camel Game) is an abstract tile placement game for the whole family published by the UNICEF association of Finland (maybe in the eighties or early nineties?). The rules recommend an even number of players.

The game includes a fairly large thin cardboard showing a two-colour drawing of the African continent filled with squares (135 of them). Some of the squares have names of African countries in them but this has no effect on gameplay. Similarly highlighted are some areas of severe drought (namely the Sahel area).

The game is played with event cards and two types of small squares of thin cardboard. One set of tiles is blue on the other side (water) and green of the other (vegetation). The second set is brown on the other side (drought) and on the reverse there can be one of three different pictures of a camel (or a note: pick up an event card).

Gameplay consists of placing a brown tile on the map, checking the size of the camel on the other side and either leaving it there, swapping it for a blue tile, flipping a blue tile green or picking up an event card and following its instructions.

An example of an event card: "Measles is a very serious disease among African children. You are vaccinating children against it. You may remove one brown tile from the board."

The goal of the game is to build a continuous green line of tiles across Africa. All players build this line together, but the winner is the one who places the last green tile to connect two opposing coasts. A slightly longer game has the players trying to fill at least half of the map with green tiles (the winner again placing the last one).

item.description:
A simulation of the battle between the Horatii and the Curiatii brothers during the war between Rome and Alba Longa (7th century BC).
Contains some element of roleplaying, as each combatant is individually created, detailed and activated.

In Tribe, four ancient races (Elves, Dwarfs, Goblins and Faeries) race to be the first to reach their tribal mount, the winner receiving the right to rule over the land for the next 400 years. To do this they must employ all of their skills to jump, climb, confuse and capture their opponents.

item.description:
Looney Tunes TAZmania game!

Players place strips of plastic, called bars, in their own side of a cage holding none other than the Tazmanian Devil in the form of a ball with his face on it. But this ball moves, and if players take enough of your bars away during play, Taz will bust through your side of the cage making you...not the winner.

Cage guards are Tweety, Sylvester, Daffy and Bugs. The cage needs adult assembly.

So you set up your cage bars as strategically as possible, crossing them if you think that may help. Then on your turn, concentrate on pulling the bars out of your opponents' sides of the cage, causing Taz to escape from any side but your own.

Computer Basics is a game to teach people basic computer skills. You roll a die, put a place holder on a square, and then answer questions from different categories (Hardware, Software, Internet, Navigation, General). If you answer the question correctly you move forward by putting your pawn where the place holder is. If you answer incorrectly it is the next player's turn. The first one to the finish wins.

Players share a pool of identical dice, each face of which shows a component of a Celtic knot work design. Each player starts with one die placed in their design. On each turn a player rolls one dice for each player, and adds one of those dice to each player's design. Designs are constrained to fit inside a 5x5 grid. When no more dice can be placed the game ends, and the player who has the single longest path with the most crossings wins.

Osbo may be played on-line at gamerz.net:

http://www.gamerz.net/pbmserv/List.php?Osbo

Full details are at the designer's web site:

http://cameronius.com/games/osbo

Players take turns adding 12 tiles of their own colour to form a single connected board. They then take turns removing tiles of their own colour. If the board is split into more than one group, the largest group only is retained. The first player to remove all of their tiles from the board wins.

Halves may be played on gamerz.net:

http://www.gamerz.net/pbmserv/List.php?Halves

and is fully described on the designer's web site:

http://cambolbro.com/games/halves/

Description from the rules file:

Goblin Slayer is a quick and easy to play fantasy boardgame of underground combat for two players.

One player controls the evil denizens of Snarlsbad Cavern, a numberless horde of goblins who jealously guard a fabulous object called the Shimmering Widget.

The other player controls Stormbeard the dwarf, armed with his legendary battle axe, who must enter Snarlsbad Cavern, acquire the Shimmering Widget and escape.

Goblin Slayer is a free print and play boardgame, and features a special geomorphic game board designed to create a "perfect" but different cave system each time the game is played.

item.description:
Supermarket Psycho confronts you with the real life horror of supermarket stress. Will you be the first to snap and - to the other player’s amusement - go crazy. And will you make them pay in the ensuing food fight?

A cardgame of sorts.

A football (soccer) card game that simulates the highlight actions of a match.
Contents of the game: 112 cards, 4 dice, 4 scheme markers (white) and 2 card-cancelling markers (orange).

Each card represents a player’s motion in attack (red) and in defence (blue), except for the goalkeeper, who only has a catch motion plus special cards. 
Each coach chooses the scheme to be used and draws 11 cards for that specific scheme (Ex. 4-4-2).
The ball handler plays a card and at the same time his opponent also plays a card. If the ball handler is playing with a defender, the opponent should contrast it with a forward card, likewise, if a midfielder is playing, the opponent should also play with a midfielder. 
The ball handler should always pass the ball to a player in a more forward, adjacent section. Only one back-pass is allowed during each action.
If the player still has the ball after playing an attack card, he may attempt to score a goal. Roll as many dice as the value of the bonuses accumulated during the action, minus the value for the goalkeeper.
Some special cards may be used to have an extra benefit in some cases.

Rules are in Italian, English and German languages.
sandrindavide@yahoo.it for info

item.description:
The object of the game is the conquest of 5 chosen squares on the first line of the opposing army. Each player makes his own choice of his objective squares, which are not known to his opponent.
A nicely made game with actual plastic soldiers!

Ninja Havoc Machines is a print and play game played on a standard chess/checkers board with some extra components.

The object of the game is to destroy all other Ninja Havoc Machines on the board. This game is very similar to Roborally in that players select a sequence of five movements (move, fire, rotate) before enacting the commands.

There is a point buy system to build your "machine" giving it different engines and weapons. The type of engine determines how fast you move. The engine also may determine the type of armor your machine has. The type of weapon how much damage you deal. Special abilities are purchased in "cpu" components.

Available for download from the designer's website:
http://www.fadupinator.com/nhm.htm
This game appeared in the October 1993 issue of Games Magazine. A player wins by preventing the opponent from moving. Tokens are not included.

This game appeared in the February, 1995 issue of Games Magazine. It actually consists of three games called "Link," "Tack," and "Fan," which are all variations on Hex. As with Hex, the object is to form a continuous chain of your stones from one end of the board to the opposite end. The stones are not included.

A game which efforts to educate and improve knot tying skills which are specific to fishing.

The opponents attempt to tie the knot on the card drawn quicker than one another, without errors, using the materials provided in the game. Whoever does so claims the points on the card.

A vast array of multiple use knots for leader tying, snelling hooks, tying smaller leader line onto fly fishing line, along with standard knots for tying baits or hooks onto monofilament or braided line are included on the card.

It's educational, and handy to keep in one's tackle box for that matter, in case of a specific knot for a specific situation is needed. Or, simply in case the fishing stinks...

Gulf, Mobile & Ohio is the third entry in Winsome Games's Historic Railroads System and is set to be released at Essen 2008 along with the second game in the series, German Railways.

Publisher John Bohrer describes it as a "No luck game about building railroads in the South, 1830-1860," and notes that "The map runs from Richmond to New Orleans, from Memphis to Savannah."

Elsewhere it is also stated that GM&O will be the "gamer's game" of the two new HRS games released this year.

item.description:
Strip – Tease The Game is just what you need to add some zing to a night of fun with your friends. As the name suggests, play Strip-Tease an you risk losing your shirt, and a great deal more... Because if another player plays a card you can not follow, you’ll have to remove the piece of clothing shown on the card... The pack also includes surprise cards and jokers that add even more spice to the game. Naturally, you can agree how far you want to go (The ‘Full Monty’ or not...) before you start.

Strip - Tease is a striptease version of UNO. But you'll lose you're clothes on the way.

Content:
94 illustrated cards
game rules

This game is excellent for children Ages 3 - 6. Cheerios Play Bingo Matching Game help children increase their vocabulary by putting their breakfast cereal playing pieces on the corresponding noun. Children are also given matching tiles, so they can work on their matching skill, for a whole new depth to the game.

This game makes breakfast just a little more educational and a lot more fun.

The Giggly-Silly bilingual descriptive word game! No reading required!

Pictures are identified to encourage early readers of both English and Spanish!Green Alligators is that wonderful little "I'm thinking of" kind of card game, but this one has pictures so you can't change your mind part way through the game! Play with your little one while doing other things around the house, just take a look at your card and start giving clues. Your little one will delight in trying to guess what your card is. Then it is the child's turn to give clues.

It is a non- competitive activity for 2 players, or it becomes competive when the "big kids" try to out guess the others!

Green Alligators is that wonderful little "I'm thinking of" card game, but this one has pictures so you can't change your mind part way through the game!

Play with your little ones while doing other things around the house. Just take a look at your card and start giving clues. They will delight in trying to guess what your card is. Then it's your childs' turn to give clues.

It is a non-competitive activity for 2 players, or it becomes competitive when the "big kids" try to out guess the others!

item.description:
Che is a board-less tile-laying game played with 64 identical two-color tiles, each with an inverse side. The tiles have the same pattern as those in Truchet (from which this game takes its name), by the same designer.

Players alternate placing tiles in an attempt to be the first to close a region of their color without also closing a region for their opponent.

Online Play

 Boardspace.net (real-time, AI option)
 Gamerz (play-by-email/web)

item.description:
"A band of Elven adventurers have got it into their heads to have a competition, to see who is the most talented Treasure Hunter of the lot. To this end, they decide to infiltrate the nearby troll caves, known for the ample treasures within, and filch the treasures."

"Completely unaware of the competition, the trolls are obviously surprised by the band of elven intruders swanning about in their caves, and understandably they are a little miffed."

"It is a race against time to amass enough treasure and get out before the trolls clobber you into oblivion!"

The object is to be the first player to find five treasures and get out of the troll caves.

Components: game board, a playing piece and stat card for each elf, a playing piece and stat card for each troll, an eight-sided die, 49 wound tokens, 24 arrow tokens, 24 mana tokens, 6 wall pieces, 2 magic door pieces, 3 sorcerer markers, 3 quiver of arrows marker, 3 magic potion markers, and the Search Deck.

"Two time traveling civilizations fight for ultimate control of the entire Time Line. The Far Future is controlled by a scientifically advanced culture known as the Teraxians. The Distant Past is controlled by a magical race known as the Atlanteans. Object: Gain control of all 12 Eras on the Time Line."

The game is played on a row of 12 spaces, each marked for a different Era: The Far Future, Near Future, WWII, WWI, Age of Imperialism, Age of Revolution, Renaissance, Middle Ages, Roman Empire, Ancient Civilizations, Prehistory, and Distant Past. Each player also has a custom deck of cards.

"Solo or Multiplayer card game. Each player is a mercenary commander leading a Squad of Meks. Meks = Giant robotic war machines with a human pilot."

"Decks: There are 4 separate common decks (each with its own discard): Mission Deck, Foe Deck, Event Deck, Build Deck. Players keep a Hand of Event cards."

"The Build deck has 4 card types: Pilots, Meks, Weapons, Equipment. Weapons and Equipment are referred to as Attachments. Weapons may be further classified as:
Energy, Ballistic, Hand-to-Hand, or Missile."

A player's Squad can consist of up to a maximum of four Meks and four Pilots. In addition, a Squad cannot have more attachments than the Meks can carry.

Each player starts with 100 Mega credits and a hand of 4 Event cards. Megacredits are earned by completing missions, with the amount depending on the Mission Threat Level.

"Victory: Be the first player to accumulate 500 Megacredits (MC)."

Based, in part, on the Mekatac game setting.

"Tile Laying game for 2+ players. Mayan City Building Theme. Victory: Score the most points by the end of the game. The game ends when all pieces (tiles) are placed or discarded."

The game is played on an 8x8 grid. A custom deck of cards and a set of tiles both depict monuments, buildings, and locations. There is a corresponding tile for every card. A random selection of cards are placed face up and the players take turn choosing cards. Once all the cards have been chosen, the players gather the pieces corresponding to their cards and take turn placing tiles on the board.

Points can be earned each time a tile is placed. The number of points depends on several factors, including the number of spaces adjacent to the tile which are occupied and whether there are plazas or causeways adjacent to the tile. Points are also earned for surrounding other tiles and filling in zones of the board.

name.value: Tales From the Mountains, The Kit Carson Card Game

item.description:
"A strategic solo card game in the life & times of the legendary Kit Carson."

The player must maintains a traveling force of mountain men, trappers, prospectors and soldiers exploring the American wilderness. Resources relied on by the expedition and tracked in the game include firearms and ammunition, horses and mules, and food and water.

"Victory: I. Live long enough to own 25 beaver pelts, II. or, Play for high score (fewest turns to victory.) Pelts cached, traded, stolen, or lost do not count towards your victory total."

Required components include two standard decks of playing cards (for the Frontier Expansion Deck and Frontier Adventure Deck), a roll of pennies (or tokens), six nickels, two dimes, a pawn, player sheet, turn sheet, and two six-sided dice (preferably red & white.)

The game also includes rules for a multi-player version.

"Another boring day at the Heroes Guildhall. There's only so much pointless killing, looting and drinking one can do before it becomes boring. What's the solution? Find a reason to kill, loot and debauch! So you have decided to quest for the legendary Keys of Fate which will open the Door of Fate in the Tower of Fate (are we sensing a theme here?), which holds the wondrous Scepter of... you guessed it, FATE! With this Scepter you will be able to rule the kingdom, which will stave off the boredom for a while at least. Unfortunately, some of your "workmates" have had the same idea (talk about coincidence), so it is a race against each other to find the keys and rule your own destiny... or at least kill a few hours in the most violent ways possible."

"Winning: There are six magical keys in the artifact deck. In order to win the game, a player must find at least four out of the six keys and are on the Tower of Fate space at the beginning of the turn. If they achieve this, they have unlocked the power of the tower and win the game.

Components: Hex map of the continent, 2 six-sided dice, 20 card Hero Deck, 28 card Spell Deck, 25 card Artifact Deck, 44 card Dungeon Deck, 50 card Equipment Deck, 15 card Villain Deck, 12 card Quest Deck, 114 card Adventure Deck, 60 Hit tokens, 60 Experience tokens, 60 Gold tokens, 20 Muscle tokens, 20 Whack tokens, 20 Magic tokens, 20 Guts tokens, 20 Sneak tokens, 20 Luck tokens, and a playing piece for each player.

"Board game for 4-8 players. Players control ancient civilizations."

The components include a map of the Mediterranean world divided up into 50 to 100 territories, different colored sets of population and city chits for each player, and a custom deck of 105 cards made up of equal numbers of the following seven card types: War, Culture, Population, Religion, Technology, Government, and Trade.

Each player starts with ten population chits in a starting territory at least five spaces from the starting territories of the other players. Each player also starts with three cards, which may be freely traded during a Trade Phase. A player's hand of card grows as the player gains more cities and population. Cards must be played to perform certain types of actions: Destroy, Grow, Convert, Colonize, Disperse, and Build.

"Victory: The first player to occupy over 50% of the territories with his chits wins."

"Two player card game simulating a joust between two competing knights. Victory: Be the first player to win 3 passes."

"The Deck: Players share a common deck. The Cards: There are four suites: 1. Speed, 2. Aim, 3. Armor, 4. Courage. Each card belongs to one Suite and has a force value from 1 to 10."

Each hand the players receive four cards face up and eight cards face down. The players must discard four of their face down cards. All of the cards are revealed and the players total the value of their cards in each suit. The goal of each hand is to have the highest score in the most number of suits. The player who does so wins the pass.

A pizza making card game for children which uses a print-and-play card deck. The cards name parts and ingredients used to make a pizza.

Points are scored by playing card combos which make a complete pizza. The basic combo, worth three points, consists of a crust card, sauce card, and cheese card. Each additional topping adds one point, and some ingredients give bonus points. In addition, there are three named combinations which score bonus points: Everything Pizza, Meatsa Pizza, and Veggie Pizza.

The game ends when a player goes to draw a card and there are none left. The player with the most points wins.

"Wargame of the American West circa 1840-1900. Players are rival Land Barons trying to gain complete control of the same territory. Victory: Control all Settlements on the Board. Players are eliminated if their Baron is killed."

The game is played on a hex map showing thirty settlements. Each player chooses to play one of four ranches and the ranches are placed on settlements that are far apart. The remaining settlement spaces have a random settlement counter placed on them. The settlements are thereby determined to be farms, mines, towns, or trading posts.

Each player starts with a Baron counter and two Regulator counters. The players gain revenue from their ranches and from other settlements they control. Revenue is used to recruit new units and to provide upkeep for the units a player controls.

"Victorian Steampunk Strategic Combat."

The players control rival forces attempting to gain control of all of the cities on the map. The game includes units and rules for aerial and naval combat forces in addition to ground forces.

The players must control resources in order to be successful. The military forces depend largely on coal. Non-infantry units use coal reserves to move. In addition, metal resources are required to build units. Coal and metal are obtained by controlling mines. The players must also control agricultural areas to provide food for the cities they control.

"Dice game simulating 2 Superheroes fighting. Victory: To win reduce your opponent to zero hits." The Superheros start with 50 hits and five Superpowers. There are approximately eighty different Superpowers defined in the rules.

Each turn the players roll five six-sided dice. The players decide which dice are being used for attack and which are being used for defense. Superpowers are then used to alter the dice in various ways. Once these effects are resolved, attack and defense totals are compared. If an attack total is higher, the defender loses a number of hits equal to the difference. If the defense total is higher, the attacker loses the hits.

"Two player Card Game based on the Games Workshop Warhammer Fantasy Universe."

The players each assemble a custom forty card play deck with a total value of 100 points or less. Each player chooses a different army from which to build a deck. There are sets of cards for the following armies, among others: Dwarf, Wood Elf, Skaven, Ork, Goblin, Lizardman, High Elf, Chaos Dwarf, and Dark Elf. Each card is rated for cost, force, and type. Some cards are also designated as Unique (one per army) or Rare (two per army).

Each play deck must include a Command Group consisting of a Hero, with a Force rating of four or more, and a Wizard. A play deck may have a maximum of twenty Item, Spell, Tactic, Mark, and Virtue cards, and a maximum of ten Wizard and Hero cards.

The are numerous card types in the game, grouped under two main classes: Units and Enhancements. Unit cards include the following types: Hero, Magic, Wizard, Archer, War Machine, Signal, Berserker, Ambush, Scout, Monster, Beast, Cavalry, Infantry, and Spear. Enhancement cards include: Item, Spell, Tactic, Mark, and Virtue.

"Victory: The first player to win 5 hands is the winner."

"Card game. Deck of 90 cards. Simulation of U-boat attacks vs allied shipping during WWII. One player is the wolf pack, the other is the allied convoy." The custom deck includes six types of cards: Target, Detection, Attack, Evasion, Water, and Discard.

The Wolf Pack player wins if six Transports are destroyed. The Convoy player wins if four U-Boats are destroyed.

The game is available to download and was also published in Strategist #337 (April 2000).

"Live and fight as a King of Hyboria!"

A strategic scale game of fantasy conquest based on the setting of the Conan novels.

There are eight unit types that make up a player's forces: Army, Elite, Hero, Wizard, Monster, Ships, King, Fortifications. Each unit type is rated for movement, initiative, and attack. Additional units in the game include neutral armies, gold, divinations, storms, curses, and relics.

Gold is gained by capturing and plundering territories. New units may be recruited from captured territories. Random events are generated each turn for Heroes and Wizards by rolling on the Heroic Actions and Wizard Magic Tables. There are also special tables for Heroic Battle Actions and Wizard Battle Spells that add flavor to the game.

A card game of competing lords who must expand their control over the lands and fill their treasuries with gold.

The players acquire and support various Resources, each of which are rated for revenue, defense points, and support requirements, if any. The Resource Cards include Villages, Towns, Mines, Castles, Cities, Knights, Ships, and Trade Routes. These efforts can be aided by Leader Cards and Advancement Cards. However, Invasion, Disaster, and Event Cards can hinder a player's efforts.

The game ends when the last card is drawn from the deck. The player with the most gold wins.

A card game of martial arts combat. The game uses a custom deck containing fifty-six cards, with eight cards for each of seven different types: Punch, Kick, Block, Grab, Move, Zen, and Combo.

The players must roll fighter characters before play. Each fighter has ten hit points and rolls ten times on a series of Maneuver Tables. This results in a list of "moves" the fighter knows and some die roll results can add hit points. Each Maneuver is rated for a cost in cards that must be played to use the move and for damage caused by the move (Attack Maneuvers) or damage negated (Defense Maneuvers).

The object of the game is to reduce your opponent to zero hit points.

"Card game for 2 players. Simplistic WWII era Pacific sea battle simulation."

The game is played with a custom deck of sixty cards. There are fifteen different cards, with four copies of each in the deck. Cards are Units, Attack, Defense, or Special. Unit and Attack cards are combined to make attacks to reduce Fleet Points, while Defense cards can negate attacks.

Each player begins with ten Fleet Points. The object of the game is to reduce your opponent to zero Fleet Points.

"Two player Card game depicting Napoleonic era warfare."

The game used three types of cards - Battalion, Commander, and Tactics. The Tactics deck is composed of maneuvers, formations, weapons, incidents, and terrain types. There is a different composition of Battalion and Commander cards given for each of the five nations represented in the game: France, Britain, Austria, Prussia, and Russia. Each player forms a Battalion Deck and selects Commander cards based on the country played.

Cards are played on the table in battlefield positions representing the Left Flank, Left Center, Center, Right Center, and Right Flank positions. The first player to be routed from three of the five forward positions loses. A player may also lose based on morale considerations.

A card game based on the manga cartoon series of the same name.

The game uses a custom set of sixty cards reflecting heroines, allies, and villains from the series. Heroines include Fuu Hououji, Hikaru Shidou, and Umi Ryuuzaki. For each heroine there are Heroine cards and Team Up cards.

The allies are Clef and Ferio. Villains include Alcione, Ascot, Caldina, Innova, Lafarga, Mokona, Presea, Princess Emeraude, Zagato. There are Plot and Villain cards for each villain.

The playing area is divided into two sides, one for each player, each consisting of a 3x3 card playing grid. Defending cards are played face down on this grid. The object of the game is to have a card reach one of your opponent's third rows at the same time that you have a card in any position on one of the opponent's other columns.

"Board game for 2-4 players. Help Harry recover the Sorcerers Stone."

Each player portrays a wizard who has several attributes, skills, and abilities which must be tracked during the course of the game: House Affiliation, Magic skill, Flying skill, Study skill, Chess skill, House Points, Clues, Wealth, Wand Type, Familiar Type, Chocolate Frogs, All Flavor Beans, and Other Possessions.

The playing board is broken into three segments - a straight track representing Dagon Alley, a loop representing Hogwarts, and a second straight track representing the Dungeon. Players move one space per turn on the straight segments and roll a die for movement on the center loop. Each space has a special table or tables that must be rolled on when a player enters the space.

"Victory: The player with the most house points at the end of the game wins. The game ends when someone defeats Voldemort in the last space of the dungeon."

"Trump taking Card game for 2 or 4 players. Based on the Hanna Barbara Cartoon Hong Kong Phooey. Winning: The player with the lowest score after 4 Rounds wins the game."

The game uses a custom deck of forty cards. There are four suits in the deck: Hong Kong Phooey, Friends, Villains, and Extras. There are ten cards in each suit, numbered 1 through 10.
